Pump and Piping Network: Energy Efficient Design, Audit and Analysis
Pump and Piping Network: Energy Efficient Design, Audit and Analysis
This intensive course is for energy professionals with pre-requisite knowledge and experience, seeking to upskill in pump and piping systems.

Pump and piping networks are widely used in process industries and many other workplaces to transport liquid between different equipment and locations. It is critical to have reliable pumps and a piping network to ensure smooth operations.

In the meantime, the pump system contributes a very big part to the utility cost. It is important to design and operate an optimal pump and piping network to run at their best efficiency points. Principle-based design, sizing, and selection process will ensure an efficient, lower-cost, and more reliable pump and piping system which requires less maintenance. This intensive course is targeted to energy professionals who have pre-requisite knowledge and work experience in energy efficiency technologies and aspire to upskill their competency in pump and piping systems.
The main objectives of this 40-hour training programme are to enable participants:
To gain in-depth knowledge of the theory and working principles of the pump and piping systems for various applications
To gain an enhanced understanding of systems vs component approach to optimise the energy efficiency of pumping systems
To be familiar with current and emerging energy-efficient pump and piping systems
To design energy-efficient pump and piping systems through theory-based calculations, and the appropriate sizing and selection process

To identify baseline energy performance of pump and piping systems, gain practical experience and self-confidence in performance evaluation and energy audit of pump and piping system, through hands-on authentic pump and piping systems
To recommend and implement energy efficiency improvement measures after conducting energy audits
Engineers and managers who are required to understand piping network in the following industries:
Process industries such as chemicals and energy, pharmaceutical engineering, food manufacturing
Bachelor Degree in Engineering or Engineering Diploma with two years of relevant working experience
Friction loss calculation in pipe and fittings
Complex piping network: series flow, parallel flow, circulation flow
Pump Types, Performance, Design, and Control
System flowrate control and energy-saving opportunities: Control valves, bypass control; and variable speed control
Using commercial software for pump and piping system
Pump and Piping System Installation and Operation
Understanding the effects of power system harmonics from inverter-controlled variable speed pump systems
Pump and piping network monitoring, monitoring the pressure and flowrate
Monitoring the drive motor, vibration monitoring, monitoring of filter
Measurement and Verification of Pump and Piping Systems
Measurement and verification to be conducted on the authentic pump and piping systems using the relevant instrument, with the understanding of its capabilities and limitations
Suitable measurement locations in the piping system, valves, fittings, pump specs and performance curves
Flowrate, pressure, power measurement, inspection and assessment of pump and piping system, control system/control room
Data Analysis and Preparation of Assessment Report
Assessment report (comprising baseline energy performance and energy efficiency improvement measures)
Associate Professor/Prog Leader, Food, Chemical and Biotechnology, Singapore Institute of Technology
Associate Professor/Prog Leader, Food, Chemical and Biotechnology, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr. Li Chuanzhao received his BEng and MEng from Tianjin University (China), and PhD degree from National University of Singapore (NUS), all in Chemical Engineering. He has worked extensively in industry, R&D and academia. He has 7 years of industry experience as process engineer and project manager in the process development, design, construction and operation of several chemical processes and plants. He has also previously worked in NUS, Institute of Chemical and Engineering Sciences (ICES) and Newcastle University. His research interests lie in process development, simulation and optimization, process engineering and process analytical technology (PAT). He has authored/co-authored more than 50 peer reviewed journal articles and 5 granted/commercialized patents.
Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology
Professor, Engineering, Singapore Institute of Technology

Dr. Lock is a Professor (Engineering) at the Singapore Institute of Technology (SIT) and the Head of its Energy Efficiency Technology Centre. He plays an active role in energy efficiency and sustainability, being the Chairman of Accreditation Committee for Energy Service Companies (ESCOs) and the Co-Chair of Steering Committee of Singapore Certified Energy Managers (SCEM) Scheme. He is an

awarded by the Uptime Institute. He is a specialist consulting engineer in the areas of mission-critical electrical design, power quality, EMC, and safety. He conducted many power failure investigations of data centres.

Professor Lock has a unique blend of practicing and academic experience acquired through a career which is equally split between the industry and the academia. He received both his B.Sc. (1975) and Ph.D. (1979) degrees in Electrical Engineering from the University of Strathclyde, UK. He was a faculty at the Department of Electrical Engineering, National University of Singapore for 17 years when he left to set up his consulting practice in 1997. He returned to the academia as a professor at SIT in 2016 after 20 years in the industry.

He is a registered Professional Engineer (Electrical) and served as a Board Member of the Professional Engineers Board, Singapore for 14 years. He is a Fellow of Academy of Engineering Singapore and an Honorary Fellow of the ASEAN Federation of Engineering Organizations.

He is the co-Laureate of the 2021 WFEO Medal for Excellence in Engineering Education awarded by the World Federation of Engineering Organisations. He received the Public Service Medal (2015) and the Public Service Star (2020).
Senior Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology
Senior Professional Officer, Singapore Institute of Technology

Joshua Chan started his career in the semiconductor industry in the areas of industrial engineering. His achievement was the setup of Singapore’s first CCD manufacturing line and clean room capability for CCD manufacturing. His training and expertise is in integrating various business process reengineering solutions and using statistical tool for process improvement in the manufacturing sector. He received both Lean and Six Sigma training which he holds a Black Belt in Six Sigma initiatives. He has also worked in other industries varying from healthcare, plastic and applied chemical industry. His experience include designing, drafting and process optimization of plastic pneumatic conveying systems. He also involved in various auditing exercises and is certified to perform audits for ISO 9001, ISO/TS19649 and ISO14001/OHSAS 18001. His working experience is diversified; working in American, British, German, Japanese and French MNCs and local SMEs as well. He joined SIT in SIT as a Senior Professional Officer and is tasked in the lab practical instruction of various thermodynamics and unit operations experiments supporting SIT Pharmaceutical Engineering program and TUM Chemical Engineering program. Besides conducting lab classes, he is involved in various student learning initiatives as well as mentoring students for industrial projects in different areas of chemical and mechanical engineering.
Principal Engineer, Energy Systems Management Ltd., and Chair of the Maintenance Engineering Society of New Zealand.
Principal Engineer, Energy Systems Management Ltd., and Chair of the Maintenance Engineering Society of New Zealand.

James has a PhD in Mechanical Engineering from the University of New South Wales and has 26 years’ experience as a professional engineer with expertise in fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, industrial energy efficiency, industrial greenhouse gas emissions reduction, acoustics, and engineering economics in both experimental and numerical modelling applications. He has a wealth of experience in working both in industry and working alongside industrial project partners to deliver successful outcomes that deliver on improved energy efficiency, increased process yields, and enhanced plant and process reliability; with a strong emphasis on realising meaningful gains in Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE). His work has included the establishment and delivery of energy auditor training and accreditation programmes for the New Zealand Industry at a national level for fan, pump, steam, compressed air, and process cooling systems.

After a 16-year stint at the University of Waikato, including the establishment and leadership of the Engineering Energy Research Centre, James is now busy working full-time in the private sector to implement change with a wide range of industry clients and partners. James and his team, work with a strong emphasis on a “total integrated systems engineering approach” to plant and process improvement that incorporates principles of energy efficiency, equipment and process reliability, and process optimisation. James has volunteered extensively both domestically and internationally to better the engineering profession, including over 16 years’ voluntary service on various committees and boards for the Society of Maintenance and Reliability Professionals (SMRP), Vibration Association of New Zealand (VANZ) and the Maintenance Engineering Society of New Zealand (MESNZ). James is the current Chair of the Maintenance Engineering Society of NZ (MESNZ).
Pump Types, Performance, Design and Control
Pump and Piping System Installation and Operation
Measurement and Verification of Pump and Piping Systems
Data Analysis and Preparation of Assessment Report
A Certificate of Attainment will be issued to participants who:
Attend at least 75% of the course
Undertake and pass non-credit bearing assessment during the course
Participants who meet the attendance requirement but do not pass the assessment will receive a Certificate of Participation.
The full fee for this course is S$5,450.00.
Funded under SkillsFuture Mid-Career Enhanced Subsidy (MCES)
All fees above include GST. GST applies to individuals and Singapore-registered companies.
